Award.AwardTitle: Food Security and Parenting Practice in the Urban U.S.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Jennifer Patico of the Georgia State University will investigate how debates about food security unfold in and across households in urban communities. Social scientists agree that contemporary Americans tend to imbue both eating and child-rearing with strong moral meanings. At the same time, they observe the "time bind" faced by double-earner families, whereby parents balance ever-lengthening professional work days with the labor of housekeeping and child-raising. The charged issue of children's food provides a strategic opportunity to examine standards for parental care and how these are negotiated under conditions of material and/or temporal strain in the United States. Based in an economically and racially diverse area of urban Atlanta, the study more specifically investigates how parental and institutional concerns about children's food might reinforce (or challenge) social inequalities by providing an arena in which the experiences, knowledge and values of different groups are communicated and/or evaluated. In-depth interviews will be held with adults from a total of sixty households that reflect the economic diversity of a local elementary and middle school. Other ethnographic methods include the observation of food-related practices within a select sample of individual households.

This study will illuminate how measures intended to improve the health of children - such as public service announcements or guidelines for "healthy" school snacks - are perceived and managed by caretakers and school employees. Further, it will show how these measures can have complex, unintended effects on the ground.

Children's food has been framed as an American "crisis" in recent years; it is a topic of active debate in the mass media, in public health research, and at the community level. These data will be of critical importance to public health professionals, school administrators, parent activists, community organizers and others who seek to mobilize concern around children's nutrition and find effective ways to shape community initiatives.

Institution.Name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

Performance_Institution.Name: Georgia State University Department of Anthropology

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the wake of a national “childhood obesity epidemic,” heated classroom cupcake wars, and other food-related health scares, the food children eat has become a topic of much attention and debate in the United States.  This ethnographic study explores how the feeding of children – and middle-class adults’ often impassioned, worried talk about the foods children eat – not only addresses nutritional concerns but expresses key values and tensions that make up contemporary American styles of selfhood.  Drawing upon 50 in-depth interviews and extensive participant-observation in one urban charter school community, I have observed how many parents carry out vigilant oversight over what their children eat (lest children fall prey to harmful chemicals, excessive sugars, and eating habits understood to threaten their physical and emotional well-being) yet also fear controlling their children too much or coming across to others as overly anxious or judgmental.  Indeed, I found that adults who were explicitly talking about fostering their children’s physical health and psychological maturity through food were also, more implicitly yet consistently, expressing standards for adult styles of selfhood and relationship.  These standards entailed navigating between over- and under-control, between restricting their children and respecting their autonomy and desires, and between monitoring the food environments through which their children moved and embracing the social diversity of their urban neighborhoods. 

Ethnographically embedding myself in school events, after-school meetings, school lunchrooms, and private homes, I observed how parents and caregivers in one Atlanta community navigated those conflicting objectives through innumerable mundane choices and commentaries: for example, when parents expressed displeasure about Rice Krispie treats being made at school, when they balanced concerns about price and appeal with healthfulness when choosing snacks to bring in for their children’s classrooms, or when they were distressed by the “fake” and “junky” snacks someone else had chosen.  Ultimately, I came to understand their strategies for managing what children ate at home and at school as part of a historically specific style of middle-class selfhood:  one that dwelt in fears over the potential health risks posed by highly processed, industrialized foods but that also idealized a calm, non-judgmental persona. Moreover, in this densely urban, gentrifying environment, parents tended to be caught between social progressivism and inclusivity on one hand and, on the other, rather exclusive, knowledge-intensive food practices and the desire to ensure that their children learned to make the “right” choices.  They championed class and race diversity, yet direct conversations about class and about the stickier aspects of relationships across social and economic difference were more elusive.

This study will contribute to the burgeoning anthropology of middle-class life and of neoliberal capitalism and how it is lived through everyday consumer experiences. Recent anthropological theory has emphasized how corporate practices, marketing rhetorics, and other economic developments give rise to particular understandings of the ideal worker, personal success, and the nature of individuality. This ethnography will explicate how the behavioral and consumer goals adults set for children – what they eat, how they learn moderation in eating – signal broader trends in the models currently available for selfhood, morality and success in cultures of capitalism in the United States. More broadly, this study contributes to the work of social theorists (including sociologists, geographers, and historians) who have analyzed the special significance attached to modern children and childhood. Hence my findings should be of interest to a broad swath of childhood studies scholars as well as consumer and food studies researchers. 

While the data collected in this project are not directly geared towards nutrition research or policy, the picture it will provide of middle-class, urban adults' nutritional knowledge may inform public health campaigns as well as approaches to nutrition education in schools. The researcher’s direct interaction with a class of middle schoolers at the research site encouraged their critical thinking about the complex roles of food in their own lives.  Ultimately, the research will provide a new perspective on parenting practices that may provoke useful conversations both locally (within the researched community) and nationally (for a broader audience of academic and lay readers).

 

  

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2017
Modified by: Jennifer Patico
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In the wake of a national "childhood obesity epidemic," heated classroom cupcake wars, and other food-related health scares, the food children eat has become a topic of much attention and debate in the United States. This ethnographic study explores how the feeding of children – and middle-class adults? often impassioned, worried talk about the foods children eat – not only addresses nutritional concerns but expresses key values and tensions that make up contemporary American styles of selfhood. Drawing upon 50 in-depth interviews and extensive participant-observation in one urban charter school community, I have observed how many parents carry out vigilant oversight over what their children eat (lest children fall prey to harmful chemicals, excessive sugars, and eating habits understood to threaten their physical and emotional well-being) yet also fear controlling their children too much or coming across to others as overly anxious or judgmental. Indeed, I found that adults who were explicitly talking about fostering their children?s physical health and psychological maturity through food were also, more implicitly yet consistently, expressing standards for adult styles of selfhood and relationship. These standards entailed navigating between over- and under-control, between restricting their children and respecting their autonomy and desires, and between monitoring the food environments through which their children moved and embracing the social diversity of their urban neighborhoods. Ethnographically embedding myself in school events, after-school meetings, school lunchrooms, and private homes, I observed how parents and caregivers in one Atlanta community navigated those conflicting objectives through innumerable mundane choices and commentaries: for example, when parents expressed displeasure about Rice Krispie treats being made at school, when they balanced concerns about price and appeal with healthfulness when choosing snacks to bring in for their children?s classrooms, or when they were distressed by the "fake" and "junky" snacks someone else had chosen. Ultimately, I came to understand their strategies for managing what children ate at home and at school as part of a historically specific style of middle-class selfhood: one that dwelt in fears over the potential health risks posed by highly processed, industrialized foods but that also idealized a calm, non-judgmental persona. Moreover, in this densely urban, gentrifying environment, parents tended to be caught between social progressivism and inclusivity on one hand and, on the other, rather exclusive, knowledge-intensive food practices and the desire to ensure that their children learned to make the "right" choices. They championed class and race diversity, yet direct conversations about class and about the stickier aspects of relationships across social and economic difference were more elusive. This study will contribute to the burgeoning anthropology of middle-class life and of neoliberal capitalism and how it is lived through everyday consumer experiences. Recent anthropological theory has emphasized how corporate practices, marketing rhetorics, and other economic developments give rise to particular understandings of the ideal worker, personal success, and the nature of individuality. This ethnography will explicate how the behavioral and consumer goals adults set for children – what they eat, how they learn moderation in eating – signal broader trends in the models currently available for selfhood, morality and success in cultures of capitalism in the United States. More broadly, this study contributes to the work of social theorists (including sociologists, geographers, and historians) who have analyzed the special significance attached to modern children and childhood. Hence my findings should be of interest to a broad swath of childhood studies scholars as well as consumer and food studies researchers. While the data collected in this project are not directly geared towards nutrition research or policy, the picture it will provide of middle-class, urban adults' nutritional knowledge may inform public health campaigns as well as approaches to nutrition education in schools. The researcher?s direct interaction with a class of middle schoolers at the research site encouraged their critical thinking about the complex roles of food in their own lives. Ultimately, the research will provide a new perspective on parenting practices that may provoke useful conversations both locally (within the researched community) and nationally (for a broader audience of academic and lay readers).
